pullRequest.body:
* Make the namespace `asPowers` to simplify/shorten names when working primarily with the power algebra construction of the free product
    * Also adds related some convenience API to `rel'`
* Add simp shortcut attribute to `lift_comp_ι` and add simp shortcut lemma `lift_algebraMap`
* Replaces some `aesop` calls with `simp_rw` for performance

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [aa59ff232e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15686/commits/aa59ff232e8599ad5bb8016b1019932b0bafb70c)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ PowerAlgebra.ofDirectSum_ι`
`+ PowerAlgebra.ι`
`+ asPowers`
`+ equiv_asPowers`
`+ identify_one`
`+ lift_algebraMap`
`+ lof`
`+ lof_map_one`
`+ mkAlgHom`
`+ mul_injections`
`+ of`
`+ rel'_cases`
`+ rel'_id`
`+ rel'_prod`
`+ rel_prod`
`+ ι'`
`+ ι_apply`
`+ ι_equiv_ι`
`+ ι_equiv_ι'`
`- _root_.LinearAlgebra.FreeProduct_ofPowers`
`- equivPowerAlgebra`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Just looking at the module docstring of this file -- it claims that in the category of commutative $R$-algebras, the coproduct is just `PiTensorProduct`. I think PiTensorProduct is much too big to be the coproduct if the indexing set is infinite. For example I think a countably infinite PiTensorProduct of 1-dimensional vector spaces over the rationals or reals is uncountably infinite-dimensional, because e.g. 1 tensor 1 tensor 1 tensor ... and 2 tensor 2 tensor 2 tensor ... are linearly independent (one is "infinitely bigger than the other"). What do you think?

> Just looking at the module docstring of this file -- it claims that in the category of commutative R -algebras, the coproduct is just `PiTensorProduct`. I think PiTensorProduct is much too big to be the coproduct if the indexing set is infinite. For example I think a countably infinite PiTensorProduct of 1-dimensional vector spaces over the rationals or reals is uncountably infinite-dimensional, because e.g. 1 tensor 1 tensor 1 tensor ... and 2 tensor 2 tensor 2 tensor ... are linearly independent (one is "infinitely bigger than the other"). What do you think?

That ... is an interesting argument. I think I would argue that _either_ we must be working over the extended reals, in which case there's something in the ring of the "correct" infinite size, _or_ the very fact that our ring doesn't have infinity in it implies that any such infinite product must "really" be an infinite limit and should be handled accordingly -- but I will freely admit I am confused on the point and I'm not sure that argument would go through in Lean.

Instead, I will retreat to the direct categorical argument. Let $A_1, A_2, B$ be $R$-algebras, then we can define the tensor product with a universal property: there exist canonical injections $\iota_1: A_1 \to A\otimes B$ and $\iota_2: A_2 \to A\otimes B$ s.t. for all $B$ and for any $f:A_1 \to B, g:A_2\to B$ whose images in $B$ commute, there exists a unique lift $h:A_1 \otimes A_2 \to B$ s.t. $h\circ\iota_1 = f$ and $h\circ\iota_2 = g$. (We have this in Mathlib as [Algebra.TensorProduct.liftEquiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/TensorProduct/Basic.html#Algebra.TensorProduct.liftEquiv).) But the universal property of the coproduct is precisely the same, except without the requirement that the images commute. Thus if the category consists only of commutative $R$-algebras, every lifted map induced by the tensor product is isomorphic to the corresponding lift by the coproduct and vice versa, thus the binary tensor product coincides with the binary coproduct, and in particular this is true of the category $R\mathbf{\text{-}CAlg}$ itself. 

I am unsure how well this argument extends to arbitrarily infinite index sets, but it should certainly extend as far as countably infinite sets at least. 

(Also this appears to be a Standard Category Theory Result, but of course in a case like this I prefer proofs by something other than authority :p)

> Thanks for your PR! Could you please address Kevin's comments and clarify the kind of this PR? You have currently written "refactor", but it adds a net 130 lines. That seems more like a "feat".

I mean, it can be a 'feat' if you want it to be! The biggest effect of this PR IMO is that there are now a bunch of lemmas that are spelled `asPowers.foo` instead of `foo_asPowers`, so I think of it as a 'refactor'; there's not much mathematical content, it's just providing different access to an equivalent formulation, plus a bunch of usability stuff like simp annotations.
Thanks for your PR! Could you please address Kevin's comments and clarify the kind of this PR? You have currently written "refactor", but it adds a net 130 lines. That seems more like a "feat".
Thanks for your PR! Could you please address Kevin's comments and clarify the kind of this PR? You have currently written "refactor", but it adds a net 130 lines. That seems more like a "feat".

```suggestion
  /--`rel` relates the image of any `(1 : A i)` to `1`.-/
```

```suggestion
  /--`rel` relates the product of the images of two terms from the same `A i` to the image of their
```
What is the logic here? Do you want both `rel.id` and `rel_id`?

`rel.id` and `rel.prod` are automatically defined by the compiler when I define `rel` above; however, they aren't terribly ergonomic to use, as Lean automatically makes `R` and `A` implicit, and I can't figure out how to override that. Rather than fight the compiler too much, I just defined a second copy with more useful binders.

```suggestion

@[inherit_doc rel.prod]
```

```suggestion

@[inherit_doc rel.prod]
```
Why `isSimp := false`?

`@[simps]` in this case produces a lemma replacing `equiv_asPowers ` with its definition... which isn't terribly friendly in this case, and certainly not a sensible default. I want the lemma to exist in case that really is the only way forward in whatever someone's use case is, but I think most users will be better served with treating `equiv_asPowers` as if it were opaque until and unless unfolding it becomes actually necessary.
Why `simp↓`?

The lhs of this definition is not in simp-normal form, but it is in, shall we say, "human-normal form" -- it's something that I expect actual users of this file to type out at some point while using it, certainly it's something I used often enough. Meanwhile, the actual simp-normal form for the lhs is an illegible mess. `@[simp↓]` marks the resulting simp lemma as a "shortcut simp" that should be applied immediately on its lhs at a high priority, before applying other simp lemmas, so that I don't need to define a separate lemma with a messy lhs just for `simp` to use.

```suggestion
@[simp↓] theorem lift_comp_ι : lift R A maps ∘ₐ ι R A i = maps := by
```

We don't match the indent of the start of the list in `simp_rw` calls
```suggestion
    ofDirectSum.toLinearMap_apply, ofDirectSum_of_tprod, tprod_apply, List.ofFn_const,
    List.replicate_one, List.prod_singleton]
```
If I must, I suppose...

```suggestion
    ofDirectSum.toLinearMap ∘ₗ PowerAlgebra.ι R A = TensorAlgebra.ι R := by
```

pullRequest.title: refactor (LinearAlgebra/FreeProduct): move PowerAlgebra construction to its own namespace, minor simp opts

source.title: feat(LinearAlgebra/FreeProduct): add induction principle, further simp opts for lift
